dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A seedy neighborhood. LARRY "DOC" SHEPHERD, wearing a hea windbreaker, stands idly on the street. An AWOL bag is on sidewalk at his feet. A garment bag is slung over his shoulder. He studies the little working-man's bar across street as the title "DECEMBER 13, 2003" comes up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Small and dark. A pool table, a few booths, not much deco SAL NEALON leans on his elbows on his side of the bar, do a crossword. He's in his late 50s and wears a cropped mustache, going gray, like the sides of his short-cropped hair. He wears a black T-shirt, revealing a USMC tattoo o his arm. He smokes a cigar, chewing its end more than it needs. An edgy dude - you wouldn't want to fuck with him. the other end of the bar, COPS is on a TV that hangs suspended from the ceiling. On the show, a nervous couple to explain to a sarcastic cop what they are doing in the projects if not buying drugs. Sal's only customer, O'TOOL an old functioning alcoholic, is watching. At some point enters, pausing near the door. O'Toole gives him a cursor glance. Doc hangs his garment bag on a hook on the stanch and takes a stool. He puts his AWOL bag on another stool settles down with a little uncertainty.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: I ask you, you ever see these cops catch a killer or a rapist on this show? Ever see them put the cuffs on some crooked CEO fuck? Wanders over to Doc.

dialogues.speaker: SAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What can I get you?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Beer.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: What kind?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Doesn't matter.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Bottle or draft?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Draft. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sal walks back over and starts filling up a glass while h continues his conversation with O'Toole.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Nah, they're always just drug users and johns... just people hurtin', trying to find a little pleasure in life.

dialogues.speaker: O'TOOLE
dialogues.text: What have you got against cops?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Nuttin'. What I got something against is good ol' stupidity. Sal wanders back to Doc and serves him the beer. Doc look into a manila envelope and withdraws a five dollar bill a lays it on the bar.

dialogues.speaker: SAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You comin' or goin'?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Passing through, kind of. (about money) Keep it. Sal takes Doc's money, puts it in the register, and goes to his crossword.

dialogues.speaker: DOC, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good beer.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's from Pennsylvania.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: How long have you had this place?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Too long.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: It's real homey.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: You think so? Where the hell do you live? Doc doesn't get Sal's wit.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: New Hampshire. Portsmouth. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sal is back on his puzzle.

dialogues.speaker: DOC, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Home of the Navy prison.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: I know the place.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: It's an okay town. (drinks) So you're Sal.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: That I am.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: So Sal, how do you suppose I knew that?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Name's on the sign outside. Doc smiles, looks around, turns to O'Toole.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Not exactly a hot spot, huh?

dialogues.speaker: O'TOOLE
dialogues.text: Not anymore.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I like it, though. It's homey.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Yeah, you said that. That's why I was worried about where you lived.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: You don't remember me, do you?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: I don't remember half the women I fucked, and that's just the ones I didn't have to pay. How am I supposed to remember you?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Well, I remember you. Sal looks at him more closely, squints. The cigar droops. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't be.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Could be.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: No way.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Way.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Sweet Jesus... Doc?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: (bemused ) Doc... Nobody's called me that ina long, long time.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Fuck me. You made it, Doc.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: O'Toole, look at this. Old buddy from 'Nam. I saved his life once.

dialogues.speaker: O'TOOLE
dialogues.text: Then you must be some kind of fuckin' hero.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: He never saved my life.

dialogues.speaker: O'TOOLE
dialogues.text: Didn't think so.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: And now he's come to kick my ass.

dialogues.speaker: O'TOOLE
dialogues.text: Long overdue and well deserved. I'll hold his coat for him.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: No, I'm not here for that.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: You gotta excuse me, Doc. I'm shit for names. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shepherd. Larry Shepherd.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Right. Shepherd. Nineteen year-old kid. Navy corpsman.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Once.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, we were all something once. Now we're something else.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: So you do remember me?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: ‘Course I do, you saved my fuckin' life.

dialogues.speaker: O'TOOLE
dialogues.text: I thought it was the other way around.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: You heard, I got busted down to E- One?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Most unfair. The green weenie - they broke it off in you. What can I say, dear, after I say I'm sorry?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: How's Mueller?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Ol' Mueller the Mauler. Maybe he's alive. How should I know? Have another beer. On the house. Fuck, I'll have one with you.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: You're not in touch with him?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Saw him medevacked out, and that's all she wrote.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Mueller got hit? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, you weren't there by then... it was not pretty. Sal now comes over closer to Doc.

dialogues.speaker: SAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I still think I rate credit for a save.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Who? What?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: You, you fuck. I saved your life.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I don't remember anything like that.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Captain said, Doc is coming unhinged. He's gonna blow. Take him for two days to Pleiku. Show him around Disneyland.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I do remember Disneyland.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Hell yeah you do.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: But all I remember is gettin' laid and drunk.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Well, yeah... that's why it was there.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Mueller was with us.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: I did that too. I said, Cap'n, Doc's too fucked up for one person to handle. Take Mueller, he said.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Oh, yeah, and things were much better after that. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, Doc, we had a good time, didn't we? We had some fun.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Sure we did. Not sayin' we didn't.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: We did, the three of us.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Yeah. I laugh sometimes when I think about it.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Really? Do you?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Yeah, kind of.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Why not? You got to laugh at every- fuckin-thing. I laugh at my prostate gland, little son of a bitch, laugh every time the doctor gives me a fingerwave, two times a year.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: It's good you know how to do that. Wish I could do that.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: So what was it, three years?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Ended up about two, with good behavior.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: That's not so bad.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: It was pretty bad, but it was a long time ago.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Yeah, but at some point instead of calling it a Bad Conduct Discharge, I started calling it a better career decision. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuckin-A. You're alive and upright. So you got out, and then what? You stayed there?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Didn't really have anywhere else to go.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Fuck all. Listen here, how did you find my lonesome ass?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Easy. On the internet. You can find anybody on the internet these days.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: That's fucked. Doc kind of laughs as O'Toole gives them fresh beers.

dialogues.speaker: SAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So whaddaya do in Portsmouth, for a living?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Stocking clerk, at the Navy Exchange.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: You're shitting me.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: (old joke between them) I wouldn't shit you, you're my favorite turd. LATER - O'Toole is asleep on the pool table. Doc is crawl into a booth. Sal is also finding a spot to lay down.

dialogues.speaker: DOC, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (stretching out) Don't you go someplace when you close?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Like where?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I don't know, home?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: It'll be there tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dreadful little space full of generational stains and graffiti. Sal washes his face, pulls out some paper towel and dries. He looks at his reflection in the mirror. This the face he has earned. This is the place he has landed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc and O'Toole are still asleep. Sal draws a beer, start eating a cold piece of pizza.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Reveille, reveille, drop your cocks and grab your socks. Reveille! Sal has to stir Doc. Finally he wakes up and looks at Sal

dialogues.speaker: SAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You want a beer? This is the last of the pizza. Doc shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: SAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm still a little fucked up from last night. I'm getting too old for this shit, frankly.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: (sitting up) What's the deal with the grill part of Sal's Bar & Grill?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Gone to rust is the deal.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Too bad.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Used to put out a righteous burger. Serious meat with a nice slice of raw onion and nothin' else, except for mustard and ketchup, of course. No lettuce or pickles or any of that crap. But people lost their taste for honest hamburgers, so I let the grill go. Why? You hungry?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Just curious. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: There's Mexicans here now, so we can get some chorizo con huevos. Hell, we qualify for menudo. You got the balls for that?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: No, thanks. There's something I'd like to show you, though, if you're up for it.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: I'm always up for it. Shoot.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: You got a car?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: I'm a fuckin businessman, of course I got a car. (stirs O'Toole) Yo, O'Toole, open up for me today, okay? O'Toole nods his head, then goes back to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not much of a car. A 20-year-old Taurus Wagon. Sal drives through a light drizzle, on a rural road.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: I just fuckin' love it, you know? It's like priceless.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: What is?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: The Navy. They put the cock to you, then they let you work at the Navy fuckin' Exchange.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I got five people under me.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: You're a fuckin' inspiration.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: You know what amazes me about you? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Could be anything. I'm a pretty amazing guy.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: You turn over your bar to a customer, you get in your car, and you drive me to hell and gone, and you don't even know where we're going.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: I didn't think it would take so fuckin' long. Doc refers to a folded up MapQuest sheet of paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A humble building that might have been a barn once. It la a steeple and stained glass, but it makes up for it with spirit we will encounter inside. We see the Taurus Wagon the parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: SAL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You gotta be kiddin' me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sal looks at the place, doubtfully.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: C'mon, you're gonna love this. I promise.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: I don't know, Doc, you seen one, you seen them all. Doc grins as they start to get out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small black congregation, listening intently to a sermo Sal and Doc enter, drawing some notice, but then space is made for them. A middle-aged preacher is at the pulpit wi the aid of a cane. It is MUELLER.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: ..--Now remember, Jesus and Judas, they were friends... As the sermon continues, Sal leans toward Doc, whispers: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Oh. My. Fucking. God. Is that who I think it is?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I told you you'd like this. Sal is wildly amused. He turns and looks around at the others, wanting to share his excitement.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: But, oh, how a good man can be laid low by a false friend, how havoc can follow the lying smile...

dialogues.speaker: CONGREGATION
dialogues.text: Amen!

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Amen, brother! (whispers to Doc) The dude was a world-class drinker, gambler and cocksman.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Shhhh.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: And likely a speed freak. How the hell did you find this place?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: The internet.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, in the spirit of friendship, have a drink... have a toke... have a snort... the devil has a friendly face and a winning way. But behind that smile, as behind the kiss of Judas...

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: (whispers) I think he's makin' this shit up just for us. Reverend Mueller eventually finishes his sermon, looking closely at his two visitors... a long judgemental look. A echoing of Amens rolls wall to wall.

dialogues.speaker: SAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (shouting out) Oh, Amen, brother! Amen! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Thank you, brothers and sisters, and praise the Lord for our fellowship here today.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Praise the Lord!

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: I see we have some visitors among us today. Welcome to our Sunday services. Would you like to stand and introduce yourselves? Sal needs no second invitation. He springs to his feet, s off a salute and sounds off:

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Salvatore Nealon, Sergeant, U.S. Marine Corps, retired. Heads in the congregation turn. Whispers become a buzz th fill the church. The Reverend totters a bit at the pulpit holding on. RUTH, Mueller's concerned wife, studies how h husband is responding. Doc tugs at Sal's sleeve, but Sal pulls him to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: SAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And guess who this lad is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mueller, Ruth and their two guests sit at a table laden w a ham and heaping bowls of vegetables and greens. Mueller sits rigidly, his eyes on Sal and Doc, wary.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Man, oh, man, southern ham, thank you, ma'am. Listen here, Ruth, I hope this old man appreciates you.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Oh, I think he does.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: ‘Cause if ever he don't, just pack a bag and come live with Sal.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: You don't have a wife? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: No, ma'am, neither chick nor child. I do have a lady friend, but she don't cook worth a damn. She has other talents, if you know what I mean. Embarrassed, she turns to Doc.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: And you, Mr. Shepherd? Are you single or married?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I married a wonderful woman, Mrs. Mueller.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Bet she don't cook like this.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I get it, Mr. Nealon, you haven't been eating well.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Am now.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: The light of my life, my Mary. A heart as big as... anything. A real pretty girl, with a great big smile...

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Nice...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: She had a little... slowness... because of a thing when she was born.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: What's that mean, she's retarded?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: No, she could do anything anybody else could, she was just kind of... delayed. A great mom, a great wife.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: What does she do? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Oh, no... I'm sorry. I lost her last January. Breast cancer.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry. Sal stops with fork in mid path.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Sorry, Doc. You know me, I didn't mean nothin’.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: We pay for the things we say, Salvatore.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Well, then you can add it to my tab.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: That's all right. You didn't know.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Your tab is long overdue, I suspect.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Do you have any children, Doc?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: (hesitates) Just one, a son. Larry Junior.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Richard and I have a boy and a girl, and we have four grandchildren.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Richard?

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: (quickly) Honey, don't you have some coffee and pie for our visitors, before we send them on their way?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: (rising) I have a peach cobbler for dessert. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Oh, man, peach cobbler... this is livin'! Ruth goes to the kitchen, looks over her shoulder at her unusual guests.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: (to Doc) I'm glad to see you prevailing over your hardships.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Doin' my best.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: You, at least, seem to have turned out to be a decent man.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Try to be.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: I regret any role I played in all that foolishness that happened back in Vietnam. Sal shakes his head, as if trying to defog his brain.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: What the hell did you do with Mueller the Mauler, preacher? He in the witness protection program or something? Where're you keepin' him?

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: I grew up, Sal, and I found a purpose along the way.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: You don't have to feel sorry.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: I always figured you for a lifer, Sal. Is that the way it worked out?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: I re-upped, sure. I was expectin' all the dominoes to start fallin', like they said they would. I was all ready to kill commies in San Diego, but they never showed up - they just all kind of disappeared. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can you believe people are now going to Vietnam on fuckin' vacations? They get their pictures taken where fifty-two thousand young Americans took their last dump. Fuck me.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: So you mustered out on principle.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: I mustered out with a plate in my fuckin' head and one-hundred percent disability. That was the good news.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: How did that happen?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Fuck if I remember. Somebody hit me on the head with something. I believe drink was involved. He laughs. The other two can't manage it. LATER - They sit in the living room having cobbler and 11 coffee. Doc hasn't touched his, Sal digs into his, while practically flirting with Ruth.

dialogues.speaker: SAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ..+.I was on the shy side of insubordination most of the time, but I could get away with it because of my dashing good looks and my boyish charm. Mueller snorts.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: I guess we're all just lucky to be alive, praise God.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: I tell myself that. Doc sits with his arms on his knees, head down, sinking d into himself. One by one they notice him. Sensing their attention, he raises his head.

dialogues.speaker: SAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (nodding to the untouched cobbler) You gonna eat that? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You okay, Doc? (a beat) What's wrong? Doc shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: It's best to talk, whatever it is that's bothering you.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: My son... because of my son, I came here, found you guys... Maybe I shouldn't have...

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Your son?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Larry Junior. A year ago he joined the corps.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Ooh-Rah.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: But two days ago they came and told me he had been killed.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Aw, shit, Doc. Why didn't you say anything earlier?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: He died in Baghdad. His convoy got ambushed, and they said he had unloaded his weapon on them and died with his bayonet in his hand. (beat) He's coming home tonight. They're gonna bury him at Arlington. Full honors. A hero. (beat) Can you guys come with me? 18. 12 LATER - Sal smokes a cigar out on the porch. He listen what is being said inside, Mueller all over Doc with symp and God. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: .»+. and I can promise you this: someday you will meet your wife and your son again, in a better place, and all of this will seem like a momentary separation. That does it. Sal tosses his cigar and goes inside.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Oh come on... what better place did they go to? Las Vegas? Miami Beach?

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Doc knows the place I speak of.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Well, then show him. Doc's got a map. Maybe he can find it on the internet.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Only when you see it will you know it, and in your case, Sergeant, it's odds-on you'll never get to see it.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Then I guess I won't miss it.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Oh, you will miss it dearly, every moment of eternity. Do you know how long eternity is?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: It ain't going to matter, but of all the billions of people floatin' around in your heaven, how come none of them ever got the word back to the rest of us?

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: One of them did.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Oh, that guy... weak on exact details, if you ask me.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: I'm not asking you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: (to Doc) Listen here, Doc, I'm sorry for your loss, but I ain't gonna blow a bunch of smoke up your ass. The worst thing that can happen to anybody has landed on you, and now you got to deal with it.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: You were a hazard when you were young, and now you're just an old fool.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: I got your fool dangling, fool.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: There he is! That's the Mueller I know!

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Please, c'mon, I didn't mean to cause trouble.

dialogues.speaker: SAL

dialogues.text: So why're we here?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: You said Arlington.

dialogues.text: That's what they said.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: But now you're saying Dover.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Yeah, I guess first... Dover. They got to fly in somewhere, so they fly to Dover. Sal looks behind at Mueller, who looks away.

dialogues.speaker: SAL

dialogues.text: (to Sal) Weren't you even listening?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Yeah, but life goes on. (beat) Don't it?

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Apparently.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Remember your first time?

dialogues.text: I told Mary all about that. I confessed to everything. I wanted no secrets from her.

dialogues.text: It was never about you getting laid, Doc. It was about Sal getting you laid.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Duh.

dialogues.text: He had to show you a good time, and he only knew his way. Ignorant soul.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: As I recall, you was there too, partaking, how shall we say, fully.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Yes, and I didn't know any more than you did what a good time was, back in those days. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Those days? It hasn't changed much. A little whorin', a little drinkin', a little fightin', all things in moderation.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Sounds like the recipe for a wasted life.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: At least it's bullshit-free.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: You positive about that? They fall silent, crossing the Severn River Bridge into Delaware.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GATEHOUSE - the Taurus Wagon is parked off to the side as three wait while the AIR PATROL GUARD finishes a phone ca

dialogues.text: Wonder if anything is wrong?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: He's a guard at a gate - he don't know nothing.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Wonder if there'll be an honor guard and all that?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: There'll be something - it'll be respectful. It's just not public - there's a blackout on all that stuff this time around.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Yeah, no pictures of coffins, no reminders to the public.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: People should know. Don't they owe it to the guys who've sacrificed?

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: People are so ready to believe in anything once it's called a war. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Call it war, you got their support. War on drugs, war on crime... it's all fake. War itself is fake. Eventually the GUARD comes to the car, and makes the gest of rolling down the window.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, the body is in transit. The plane's not due 'til 0800 tomorrow. Come back then and you'll be able to wait in the hangar.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Okay. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: In transit. Somebody's always in transit, even...

dialogues.text: A cheerless refuge from the rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guys are in mid check-in.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: I thought I'd have my own room.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Don't get cranky on us old man. Doc takes cash out of his envelope.

dialogues.speaker: SAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Whoa... what's with the wad?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: They took up a collection at the Exchange, when they heard.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: See? You got lots of friends.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: They felt bad. They wanted to do something. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 22 23 29. A HYPED-UP EMPLOYEE enters the front area and changes the channel on the TV that rumbles in the background.

dialogues.speaker: HYPED-UP EMPLOYEE
dialogues.text: You guys aren't watching this?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: HYPED-UP EMPLOYEE
dialogues.text: They got him!

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: HYPED-UP EMPLOYEE
dialogues.text: That sumbitch Saddam! They got him in a spider hole! He finds a news station that is showing some footage of t captured Saddam Hussein, submitting to an inspection of b etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two queen beds, a TV going with the Hussein footage, and empty pizza box at the foot of the bed. Doc already looks asleep, while Mueller lays on his bed, almost asleep.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: How's the rack, Padre?

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: It's fine. Here they are, but where are they? Nothing to do, nowhere go. Sal just finishes the last piece of pizza and stares more Saddam Hussein footage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They make their way to the car and throw their bags into trunk.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I was wondering...you never went home, so how did you get to pack a bag?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: I always keep one in the trunk. Sometimes a lady friend wants me to stay over. I hate to say no. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: Is there one particular lady friend or are there more?

dialogues.speaker: SAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cold and hollow and cheerless. A folding table has been s up with coffee and doughnuts. Only Sal partakes. Across t hangar is a MOTHER, weeping. Her eyes are red from crying She holds a hanky against her face. Her HUSBAND is a larg man, a working man, and he is angry.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: (through tears) I want him to look nice...

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Irene, that ain't gonna be the boy that walked out of our house, that waved good-bye. Another circle of four - mother, father, second wife, sec husband - huddle together. One more circle of three waits mother, father and daughter. The hangar door slides open. An Army major and a Marine L Colonel come in. dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: Mister Shepherd? Sal nods to Doc, who stands dumbly, his eyes on the flag- covered box that contains his son. The Colonel extends hi hand. Doc shakes it. COLONEL (CONT’D) Mr. Shepherd, I'm Colonel Willits. The President of the United States has asked me to express his deep regret that your son was killed in action. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: Sal can't help himself and rolls his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.text: He died a hero in the service of his country. He was an inspiration to his fellow Marines. 31. WASHINGTON, the escort, stands at stony attention. dialogues.text: Take the Colonel's advice, Doc. Best to remember him as he was. Doc thinks about it, looks to Sal.

dialogues.text: I'd have to see him, but that's me. The thing is, you don't have to listen to no colonels no more. Those days are gone. The Colonel seems to recoil, his jaw tightens. Washington sees it and twitches. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.text: I'm sorry sir, but there is always a sound reason for my recommendations. Doc is trembling, unable to speak. Sal puts a hand on his shoulder. Doc goes into his arms. Sal holds him awkwardly These men are not used to hugs. He pats his back.

dialogues.speaker: SAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How'd this boy wind up dead, mister? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: Sal...

dialogues.text: Shouldn't we be making arrangements for the funeral. Isn't that why we're here?

dialogues.text: Were you there, when it happened? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: No, I wasn't.

dialogues.text: I was there, sir. The Colonel doesn't like how this is going at all, but it too late.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Where are we with this?

dialogues.text: Where we was, pretty much. He'd like his son's face back.

dialogues.text: I called my wife. I'm going home. I'll take the bus.

dialogues.text: You quittin'?

dialogues.text: Quitting what? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: We'll know in a minute or two. Sal sees the Colonel once again approaching Doc so he wan over to him.

dialogues.speaker: SAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yo, Doc. Doc looks up.

dialogues.speaker: SAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What's it gonna be here? Doc stands up straight, looks the Colonel in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I can't bury him in Arlington. Not now.
