dialogues.text: He qualifies and he deserves that honor. Doc digs out his wallet, rifles through it, and produces photo of his son. He holds it out, in front of the Colone face.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Here, this is what his face looked like. He was a good-looking boy. (shows the photo to the others) See? The high school girls were all over him. He was a good-looking boy. I'm taking Larry home.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WILLITS
dialogues.text: I assure you that is a bad decision and you will come to regret it. Doc tries to push the cart. Sal hands his cup to Mueller joins him. They push together.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WILLITS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hold on. The Marines will transport the body, at no cost to you, anywhere you choose. They keep on pushing. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WILLITS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Gentlemen. I cannot release the Lance Corporal's body, except to a licensed mortician... Mueller steps up.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Or to a clergyman, isn't that the case? The Colonel hesitates, as Mueller hands him Sal's cup and begins to put on his clerical collar.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WILLITS
dialogues.text: Correct.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: So I guess that would be me. Using his cane, Mueller walks behind Doc and Sal as they the coffin. Washington stands next to the Colonel, impres EXT. HANGAR PARKING LOT —- MORNING 26 Sal and Doc push the cart, Mueller trailing behind. They to a stop, not before dinging the car.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Sorry about that.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Forget about it. They stand silently, awkwardly for a moment. What now?

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Now how you gonna get him home? Strap that coffin to the roof of Sal's car?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: We could do that. We'd need help liftin' it up. Maybe we...

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Don't be ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Why not? Tell me a better way to be. You wish you could be ridiculous, but it's too late now. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Doc, let the government take care of the transport - that's the kinda thing they're good at.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I don't like the government right now.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: You don't have to.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I don't trust it any more.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Hell, we could rent a truck.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Yeah, let's do that. We'll stay here, and you can take the car and go find a truck. Pay for it out of this. Doc gives him an envelope full of cash.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Consider it done. One truck, comin' up.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: (to Doc) I'll be going with Sal. He can drop me at the bus station. I think I'll be going back home now. For a moment no one says anything.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I understand, Mueller. I'm sorry for dragging you up here.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: I thought I could be of some help. I thought we were going to a funeral.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: We ARE going to a funeral, it just looks like it's going to take a little longer to get there. Doc doesn't want to make this any harder than it is. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: It's okay, Mueller. I'm just glad I got to see you again.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, lad. A handshake and a hug, awkwardly trapping his cane agains him.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Glad I got to see you too. God bless you, Doc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sal drives, Mueller next to him. They maintain a silence, then -

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: We should stop and ask somebody where the bus station is.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: It's a small town, we'll run into it. Give you a few more minutes to enjoy my company.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Always a pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Before you bail on us. Mueller stares straight ahead.

dialogues.speaker: SAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So, what's on your agenda? Read the bible all the way home, leftover ham for supper, say a little prayer...

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Oh, I'll say a little prayer long before that. The bigger question is, what's on your agenda?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: I feel I owe him one. Nothin' more, nothin' less.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Even though he says you don't owe him a thing? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: All the more reason.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: What would have happened, way back then, if we hadn't... you know?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Doc wouldn't have ended up doing two years in the brig, that's for sure. And we wouldn't have had to see what we did.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: What was that?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: You don't remember?

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: I remember a lot of shit... what are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: A certain platoon buddy, shot, writhing around on the ground dying, with nothing to help him cause we'd taken all the morphine for ourselves.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: He was going to die, anyway. He had no chance. Minutes.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: There was nothing we could do at that point.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Yeah, and we did nothin'. Sometimes you ought to do a little more. Sal sees a Ryder agency and pulls to the curb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A nervous older WOMAN, smoking a cigarette, is behind the counter, dealing with Sal and Mueller. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: I have a van that would work for you, but you might be happier with a truck that's got a hydraulic tail lift.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Ohhh, a hydraulic lift. I like it.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: What will you be hauling?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: (hesitates) Your truck with the lift'll handle it.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Will you be dropping it off back here or at another location? It catches Sal short. He hadn't thought about that. WOMAN (CONT’D) Don'tcha know?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Guess I'm gonna return it here.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: And when will that be? Again, Sal has to think about it. The agent's suspicions start to grow. She grows more nervous. Terrorists? WOMAN (CONT’D) You don't know how long you'll need it?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Better give me a week.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Oh my, a week, he says. Now she looks uneasily at Mueller as she taps her keyboar

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Now Mueller, it's outta your hands now. At "Mueller," the agent's head jerks slightly, not sure w she heard. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ... Just have a seat and take a load off. I'll handle this. Mueller makes his way to a chair and sits. The woman is fretting inwardly.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: I need to see your driver's license.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am. He empties one pocket of change and keys and a cigar cutt The woman looks at that with apprehension. Out of the oth pocket: cash, cards and hard candy. He finds the license.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Norfolk, Virginia?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Gotta live somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: What brings you up here?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: With all due respect, that's none of your business. Now she's really worried.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Just trying to be friendly.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Really? Okay. Well, I'm here because of a death in the family.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: (smiling) That's all right. It wasn't my family.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Will you be the only driver? Again, he has to think about it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll have some help.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Then I'll need to see the other driver's license. Is it that gentleman there?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: His holiness? His holiness can't hardly walk, let alone handle a big rig with a hydraulic lift.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Whoever, I'll need their license.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: I'll drive it myself.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: So you are the only driver?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am. I be the wheelman. Paranoia deepens.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Insurance on the vehicle?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: What about it?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Would you like to get some?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Not necessary.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: How will you be paying?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Cash. He pulls out Doc's brown envelope.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: And get directions.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, where's the bus station? She can't wait to call the police.  47.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sal and Mueller are driving along in the rented truck.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Sixteen or sixty, put a dude behind the wheel of a big rig, got to feel like hot shit.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: It's a rented U-Haul with an automatic transmission.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Bigger than anything you ever handled.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Look Sal, Doc's boy is dead. Try not to forget that.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: I haven't forgotten that. But we're still alive, right? With time tickin' fast away. If a minute comes up that's not too terrible, I'm gonna try to enjoy it. You used to be up for some fun.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Still am.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Really?!

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: As long it's right in God's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: ‘God's eyes?' God don't have no eyes.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Oh, He's got eyes. And ears too. He hears every insult you send His way. There will be a reckoning, Sergeant.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: A reckoning?

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: I assure you of that. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Then great - then I reckon I'll take that opportunity to stand at attention and say to God, "Hey, where were You when they were rapin' children or with the genocide and all that? Where were You when they flew airplanes into buildings, killin' thousands of folks just goin' to work, and the murderers shouting Your name, or You by some other name. Same difference. Where were You when Doc's kid was buyin' Cokes and some raghead blew his face off?" You see, I ain't gonna explain myself to God, I'm gonna make Him explain Himself to me!

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: I'm going to pray for your soul.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: And I'm bettin' at the end of it, if the fucker even exists he'll say "Get your ass in here, you're my kind of dude." (beat) At least that's what I'm hopin'. If He's a tight-ass God, I'm fucked.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: It might be time for a lube job on that plate you got in your head.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Don't fuck with my plate, it's pickin' up WOR in New York. Mueller just stares at him. Sal notices the radio.

dialogues.speaker: SAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Looky here. He turns it on. Rap music. An Eminem song (something from "The Eminem Show").

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Turn that shit off.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: (he doesn't) You've heard this stuff, right? (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now, I've been known to get ina face or two, but even I find some of this stuff offensive. And damn hard to dance to...

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: For once you and I agree on something.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Don't it make you a little ashamed to be an African American?

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: No, not really.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Well, it ought to, dignified old gentleman like you, who'd be the first to agree just how far this stuff is from Motown.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Why should I feel ashamed? This dude is white. The fuck ...!?

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: That's affirmative. White as rice.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: That's comin' out of a white mouth?

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Yep - a white sewer mouth.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Then, by God, fuck me. I ought to feel ashamed myself. Only I never did much identify with the white race.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Oh really? Now I'm curious. What race do you identify with?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Green. The corps - that was the only culture ever made any sense to me. (beat) You ever miss it? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Not for a minute.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: I don't believe you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sal carries Mueller's bag and waits while Mueller hobbles back with his ticket in hand.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: No problem?

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Not unless being stuck on a bus for the next seven hours is a problem.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Busses are real nice now. Recliners, a shitter in the back. Maybe you'll meet some poor redneck and save his soul. How many points you get for that? Is it a point system?

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: I'm just hoping I can sleep. I didn't sleep too well last night.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Me either. Remember when we could sleep in a hole in the ground, with bullets zinging just overhead?

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: You can't go back, Sal.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Who'd want to?

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: We can't redo the choices we made back then. All we can do is learn from them and try to do better in the future.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know that.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: But you're still gonna do it, aren't you? (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're gonna take Doc and his dead son to Portsmouth and try to make it fun.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: You ought to come with.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Can't do that.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: All right. Well, I'd better get started. He extends his hand and they share an affectionate shake.

dialogues.speaker: SAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I still can't believe it, you of all people, a preacher.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Goddam right.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Think we'll ever bump into each other again? We're not that far away.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Never know. He moves in mysterious ways.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The back of the parked truck is open and Doc pushes the coffin up to it as Sal joins him.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: This is a lot of truck.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Never go small, kid. Check this out. He pulls a small lever and raises the lift up to the leve the coffin. Together they half-slide, half-lift it off th wagon and onto the lift. Sal leans back against the lift lights a cigar.

dialogues.speaker: SAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I was wondering, though. What would your kid have wanted? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 32 33 52. Doc thinks about it for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: To drink beer with his friends. Chase girls. He was twenty-one, he wasn't thinking about dying.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: You can make this a lot easier on yourself.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I don't want to make it easier on myself.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: (chuckles ) Yeah. Guys like you and me, we take all the shit ‘til it's disaster, and then we're cool, the worst has happened, like we always knew it would.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: They sent him to a God-forsaken desert because... who knows why? It wasn't to protect America. It's like that jungle they sent us to. It wasn't a threat to us. And then they sent him back to me in this, with more lies... a hero, honors, Arlington. I ain't going to bury no Marine. I gotta bury a son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Washington stands outside the hangar, watching the U-Haul truck pull away, wistfully. Then he walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sal drives toward the gate.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Some rig, huh? Doc doesn't answer but is looking out the window. Somethi wrong. A DAFB Police Car pulls in front of them, slows, bringing them almost to a stop. Another Police Car blocks them from behind, trapping them. They come to a stop.

dialogues.speaker: BULLHORN VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Get out of the truck. Walk away, hands above your head.  34 53.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mueller sits in the waiting area, quietly reading his bib A man in a cheap RAINCOAT is talking to the ticket agent, looking over at Mueller. Another man in a black ANORAK ta a seat next to him.

dialogues.speaker: ANORAK
dialogues.text: Taking a bus today?

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Yes, to Richmond. And you?

dialogues.speaker: ANORAK
dialogues.text: Richmond, huh. That home for you?

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: No, but it's getting close. Why? Cheap Raincoat has walked over and is standing in front o Mueller.

dialogues.speaker: RAINCOAT
dialogues.text: You're the one they call the Mullah?

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: The what?

dialogues.speaker: RAINCOAT
dialogues.text: Mullah.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: I'm waiting for a bus to Richmond, reading the scriptures.

dialogues.speaker: ANORAK
dialogues.text: What, the Bible? Checking out the competition?

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Who are you two? What do you want from me?

dialogues.speaker: ANORAK
dialogues.text: That depends.

dialogues.speaker: RAINCOAT
dialogues.text: We're from Homeland Security.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sal crushes an empty Bud can and tosses it the length of room, missing the basket. As he grabs for a fresh one, Do retrieves the empty and deposits it on top of the others the plastic-lined wastebasket of the very same room they occupied the night before. Sal pops another can.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: It used to mean something. There used to be an esprit de corps, a unity, a well-earned pride, some goddamn common sense. I don't know what it means anymore.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Fuck 'em. Fuck ‘em all.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Fuck ‘em all! I spent the best years of my life defendin' this country.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I think your best years are still ahead of you, Sal.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: It's true. It can be true.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Will you sit the fuck down? Look at me - all my future is behind me. I got a scrambled brain held together with a steel plate. And they look at me and what do they see? A fuckin' terrorist!

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: An apology would have been nice.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Oh they're sorry. Sorry they didn't smoke our asses. A KNOCK on the door. They look at each other, like, what Sal eventually shrugs his shoulders and Doc cautiously op the door. Mueller steps in and drops his bag. He stares d Sal. Sal gets off the bed he's been sitting on, Mueller's bed. He smooths it, and steps aside. Mueller lies down in overcoat. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You forget your toothbrush? Mueller says nothing. He needs a moment. Then -

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: I called my wife from the police station. The damn police station. Only after they decided I was not a Muslim radical. And not a mullah, but an old preacher named Mueller. Sal thinks this is hilarious.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Mullah the Mauler! Its all over - this country's fucked.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Was Ruth upset?

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, she wanted me to come right home. But I told her that when times demand it, even old men should become threats.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Fuckin' A right it is! It's like during the pinko scare....

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: (icily) I believe I was talking. Sal raises his hands - sorry and continue.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I told my wife I was not coming home until we were done. Where's your boy?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: They've got him again.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Tomorrow we get him back and take him home.  56.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our three come into the lobby and are met by the Lt. Colo and Washington.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WILLITS
dialogues.text: Good morning, gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: What's the deal, colonel whatever your name is - where's Larry?

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WILLITS
dialogues.text: Willits. Colonel Willits. I've been briefed on last night's snafu. Totally ridiculous, the rental agent apparently went off the deep end, but there it is and what's done is done. He addresses Doc.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WILLITS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I hope, given further time for reflection, that you can see that Arlington is a resting place that should not be refused in anger. There lie heroes. The details of the Lance Corporal's death are what they are, but make no mistake: his death was heroic. He was in a foreign and hostile land doing the decent thing. He deserves to lie beneath the sacred soil of Arlington. He would want that. I urge you to choose that for him.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Thank you. I'm gonna take my son home and bury him in New Hampshire. Not in his uniform. I'm going to bury him in his graduation suit.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WILLITS
dialogues.text: As you wish. Your government will fly the coffin, at no expense to you, to Portsmouth and a funeral director of your choice.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: No, we're taking him with us now. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WILLITS
dialogues.text: With all due respect, you're cutting off your nose to spite your face.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Take a look at these faces. Think any of them care about your fuckin' opinions? With all due respect.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: We can go by train. They all kind of look at each other for a moment and arri at a consensual "why not?"

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WILLITS
dialogues.text: Okay, I'll make the arrangements. (punches out a number on his cell phone) Lance Corporal Washington here will be going with you. (in phone) Colonel Willits here. You are going to make a few things happen, ASAP.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Hold on, Colonel, we don't need no babysitter.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WILLITS
dialogues.text: (in phone) Stand by. (to Sal) I wasn't implying you did. Washington's on TDY, escort duty. You don't want him, he goes right back to Baghdad.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Guys?

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: We could use the help.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Does he pull per diem?

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WILLITS
dialogues.text: Of course. Sal grins at Washington. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Then fall in, Washington! (to Colonel) But he takes his orders from us.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WILLITS
dialogues.text: He takes his orders from ME. But, he will accommodate you in any reasonable way you ask, because I just ordered him to. Is that clear?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Well, you're a fuckin' force of nature, ain't you? It would have been fun to run into you in the field in my younger days.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WILLITS
dialogues.text: You think so?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: One of us woulda got fragged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody is back at the hangar where the casket has been taken. They see six more flag-draped coffins being wheele into the hangar. Their casket is loaded onto one carryall while the civilians pull away in another. Sal turns back see Washington, in the distance, standing at attention wi the Colonel in his face.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WILLITS
dialogues.text: I don't give a fuck what they say. The Lance Corporal is ours. He's a Marine until he goes into the ground, and he remains a Marine for the period he is under the ground, plus one hundred years. I will not have three over-the-hill veterans pissing on my corps. Is that understood?

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Yes, sir!

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WILLITS
dialogues.text: You're a Marine, and your mission is to see your brother home. You're in charge, and when IN charge, TAKE charge. Understood? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Yes, sir!

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WILLITS
dialogues.text: There's going to be a mortuary affairs detail at every step of the trip. You will protect the dignity of that dead Marine, and see that he is buried with honors. In his uniform. Not in some pussy civilian graduation suit! Understood?

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Yes, sir!

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WILLITS
dialogues.text: And don't let that Sal asshole outflank you. He's old but he's dangerous. Don't let that happen - kill him first.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WILLITS
dialogues.text: That is not an order.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WILLITS
dialogues.text: And just because that crippled preacher reminds you of your father, don't trust him.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: I never knew my father, sir.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WILLITS
dialogues.text: Lance Corporal, do you have a personal problem?

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: No, sir!

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WILLITS
dialogues.text: Then get on it.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Yes, sir! He jumps into the other carryall and it takes off.  38 39 60.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alongside the train at the Wilmington, Delaware station, "mortuary detail" of six service members, including Washington, carry the box containing the coffin. They eventually load the container onto a cargo car. Washingto stands next to it in the car and salutes, as do the other five, before walking away. Doc stands back a little as Sa chats with the attendant, JOHN REDMAN, who also saluted.

dialogues.speaker: REDMAN
dialogues.text: I was there the first time. Gulf War, they called it then.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: You got back.

dialogues.speaker: REDMAN
dialogues.text: Yeah, and I'm not pissin' blood and my babies are all okay. Filthy little war. But righteous.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Oh yeah...

dialogues.speaker: REDMAN
dialogues.text: Can't let the big ones swallow up the little ones. Redman turns to Doc and shakes his hand.

dialogues.speaker: REDMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: John Redman. Don't worry - I'll look after your boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sal and Doc sit next to each other, facing Mueller, who's reading his bible. Sal watches him read.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: When did you become so old?

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: I think it happened over the past thirty years. Same as you.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: I categorically deny it.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: You can deny it all you want to, but that ain't gonna stop the clock or turn it back. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: What do you make of that grunt, Washington?

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: What about him?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: I don't know, he don't say much, him and his Baghdad boil... that's some gnarly shit.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: What do you want to know about him?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: I don't want to know nothin' about him.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Sounds to me like he is an individual heavy on your mind.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Nothin' heavy about it. Just wonderin’.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Go back and talk to him, if he's such a mystery to you.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Everything's a mystery to me... except you.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: I think I'll go back and talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: I'm sure he'll enjoy that.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Tell him he can come sit up here with us.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: I'll do an invite.  40 4l 62.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alone in the restroom, Sal takes a toke on a joint, wavin away the smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sal enters, slowly walking over to Washington, sitting ne to the coffin.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: You're welcome.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Are you on a train in Baghdad? No, you're not. Washington just kind of nods as Sal finds a seat on some boxes.

dialogues.speaker: SAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: TDY. Sometimes it's fun, sometimes it's a bitch.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: I don't mind. He was my best friend.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: You didn't hang with the brothers? Washington looks up at him.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: There's no rule. I just liked the dude. He had my back and I had his. He was honest, said what he thought. Simple, in a good way. He never had an attitude.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Sounds a lot like his father.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: What about the honest part?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Doc is not a dishonest man.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: What about that brig time? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 42 EXT. /INT. The train 63.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: That could have been any of us. He got fucked. I know things you don't.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Doc was a lot younger than us, a kid, and technically he was in the Navy. He wanted to be our friend and we took advantage of it. We'd done him a favor and now he was doing one for us. But then it all went to shit and someone had to take the fall. C'mon up with us for a while. Redman here will look after your friend.

dialogues.speaker: REDMAN
dialogues.text: No problem.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: That's all right.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: No, you have to get out of here for a while.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Come talk to Larry's father, say something nice.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: I don't know what I can say.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: You'll come up with something.

dialogues.speaker: PHILADELPHIA STATION
dialogues.text: pulls into the station.

dialogues.speaker: CONDUCTOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Philadelphia... Arriving Philadelphia.  43 64.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Washington sits with the others, a bit uncomfortable. The look out the window at the people on the platform, waitin for the train, carrying shopping bags. Finally -

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Look at them.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Them. All the shit they bought. They don't have a clue.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Ordinary people, out for a day of shopping.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Fuckin' sheep is what they are.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: I wouldn't mind being one of them.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Well, yeah, it's better than being shot at.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Rather be fighting them over there than in our own backyard.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Sound familiar?

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Oh yeah...

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: (to Washington) See, we fought the commies in 'Nam so we wouldn't have to fight them on the beaches of Malibu.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Guess it worked. (a beat) Marine's gotta be willing to die on order. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Yep - that's always been the mission, and it's a bunch of crap.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: There needs to be a reason. This time we were told there was an imminent danger. Arsenals of horrible weapons... a possible mushroom cloud.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Lies. It's always the same ol' shit: stay the course, if we pull out now, our heroes will have died in vain...

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: But I want to believe in our leaders, I want to believe in our country. We're a good country.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Yes we are, but when you catch your government lying to you, everything changes. Passengers hurry on board. The doors shut and the train p away.

dialogues.speaker: SAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So, how's the living over there?

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: It's all right. They got a shopping mall out near the airport. There's a new Burger King and Pizza Hut. We're livin' pretty good for a combat zone, but they sure hate us.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: We gotta be the only occupying force in histroy that expects people to like us.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: When you go out, you never know what's gonna happen. But coming from Oakland, I'm used to people dying all of a sudden.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Really? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: In high school, one of my best friends was killed by a stray bullet. My father was robbed on the street, and they put one in him. But I didn't even know who he was ‘til he turned up dead.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Jesus, kid...

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: I'm only sayin’...

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: So you joined the Marines to get away from all that in Oakland?

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: No, sir. I wanted to strengthen my character. It was that way with Larry too. We wanted to test ourselves, to forge ourselves into the men we wanted to become.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: That's what we used to think. Every generation has their war. Men make wars, and wars make men... Never gonna end.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Maybe we need to try something else.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: When Larry was little, he played with toy soldiers. He dug trenches for them. He put them through basic training.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Mr. Shepherd, Larry was where he wanted to be. He hated it. We all hate it. But it's where we were sent, and we'll do what we have to do. We signed up for it.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: He must have been embarrassed, me sitting out the last part of our war in the brig... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: No, sir, Larry wasn't embarrassed - he loved you. You know what made him different from most of us in the unit?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: He had a happy childhood.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: He said that?

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. He had a mother and father who loved him... and each other. Nice house to live in. Good food to eat. School... football... nice friends... on and on. (beat) Mr. Shepherd, it was my turn to get the Cokes. That was my bullet, not Larry's. I should have been the one... Mueller puts his hand on Washington's knee, letting him k it's okay and not to think like that.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: A gray car pulled up to the house... a Marine Lieutenant and a Navy chaplain. Shiny brass belt buckles. I kept looking at those shiny buckles. "The President has asked me to express his deep regret..." Killed in action. In action - nothing about shot in the back of the head buying Cokes for the guys. Nothing about killed trying to get the Baghdad school system up and running. (looks out the window, looks back) The school system in New Hampshire is in rough shape. (beat) Why wasn't Larry back in New Hampshire delivering stuff to our own schools? Nobody can say anything. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DOC, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is that a stupid question?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With two glasses of beer, Sal wanders from the bar over t the table where Doc and Mueller sit. Mueller has a cup of coffee, and Doc a beer. As soon as Sal sits he downs a gl in one gulp.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Thirsty?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: That went down awfully fast.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Well I'm drinking for two, now that you've got all old and boring. He starts to drink the other glass.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Might be you're an alcoholic. I am. I recognized that and owned up to it. That's the first step.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: At least we're not drug addicts.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Not anymore, praise Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: We never were.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: We took the shit, didn't we?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: We needed the shit.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: If we needed it the corps would have issued it to us.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: In a way they did. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: That shit was meant for pain. All drugs are.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: So what's wrong with takin 'em then?

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Morphine? It's kind of addictive.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: So's pain.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: We weren't the ones who were in pain, though.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: The fuck we weren't.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: That's a different kind of pain.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Pain is pain.

dialogues.speaker: SAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Back from the war less than a day, his best buddy in a coffin, and all he's talking about is a Burger King and Pizza Hut at the shopping mall.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: He just doesn't want to talk about it. We never did.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: You asked him. (new thought) Next stop I need to call Ruth.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: You need one of those mobile phones. You could be talking to her right now. Ten year-old kids have ‘em. They've practically quit making pay phones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the train speeds to New York, we hear all the guys in conversation. This time, however, it is revved up and boisterous. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: «+. So we ended up at Disneyland to resuscitate Doc, who was metaphorically drowning...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guys sit on improvised seats in the baggage car, bull shitting.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: I got your metaphoricals - dangling! Stick to the story!

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. They got a Disneyland in Vietnam? Everybody laughs.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: That's what they called all the bars and houses of ill-repute that sprung up near the base.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: And it was the company fucking commander's doing! He's the one who told us to take a couple of days off and get Doc's ass over to Disneyland before he had a total meltdown.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I was having some problems...

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: He sure as shit was, and the biggest one was that it was time for him to get his cherry busted. How old were you, Washington, first time?

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Thirteen.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: I rest my fucking case! My point exactly. Doc was eighteen.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I was nineteen. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: One year worse. It was time.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: No, it wasn't. The right time was when I met Mary, and we committed to each other.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: I think thirteen is way too early, too, by the way.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Don't wreck my story. Believe me kid, he was ready. We killed some time in the bars then found the perfect little whorehouse.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: That's so uncool.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Paying for sex. Whores and pimps... it's disgusting.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Jesus, what the hell has happened to your basic GI?

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: I just think some things shouldn't to be bought and sold.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Actually, it wasn't all that bad. The others laugh. Mueller leans a little toward Washingto

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Jesus had not yet entered my life. I yielded to bad impulses.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Yielded to 'em? You smoked ‘em, drank ‘em, and fucked every impulse! Old Mueller the Mauler here would get the five dollars/ five minute special - he was like a jackrabbit. Sal makes a quick humping motion. Mueller fights a smile. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Everything seems funny years later, but I don't care what anybody says, it was a dereliction of duty, pure and simple.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: I got your dir'liction swinging, you old coot!

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: The whores I know, I don't want to be around.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: But this was like going to a friend's house... and then you end up having sex with the friend. And then you pay them. They laugh again. In spite of everything, they are having good time... a good moment at least.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Next day, I gotta admit, I was sick of hearing about that little Asian whore. Oh, Doc was quite proud of himself. Said he had a hard-on so big he couldn't bend his fingers or blink his eyes. Another round of big laughs.

dialogues.speaker: SAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fuck me... God, I really miss that, having a boner you can hang a towel on. My johnson used to stand up and watch me shave, now it watches me pull up my socks. They all crack up.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Don't encourage him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train is grinding to a stop in Penn Station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our three walk downtown, away from the station. Sal takes deep breath. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: New York, New fucking York.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Let's not wander too far.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Just far enough to find the first Blarney Stone. Which is right across the street. Sal turns and goes insi The others have no choice but to follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sit at the bar. Sal has escalated to a shot and a be Mueller has a ginger ale; Doc, a beer.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: How much time do we have?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Enjoy, old man. It's the Big Apple. We got the time.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: I have to call my wife.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: See? Again, you need a fuckin' wireless telephone. You could sit right here and dial her up and you wouldn't have to get off the stool and hobble the full length of this place and have to stand on your feet next to the shitter just to say, "I miss you, dear, I hope you still love me, even though I used to fuck whores." Though on his way, Mueller swings his cane around toward Sal's head, just missing as Sal ducks.

dialogues.speaker: SAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm still too quick for you, floatin' like a butterfly. Mueller continues on as Sal waves to the bartender.

dialogues.speaker: SAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: One more, please, before Grandpa Moses gets back. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bartender pours another shot. Doc takes some money ou his brown envelope.

dialogues.speaker: SAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Drink up. Here's to duty and honor. Sal knocks back the shot.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I guess it woulda been an honor, the whole Arlington thing.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Sometimes the real honor is turning down the honor.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Wouldn't you be honored?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Don't matter to me. Drop me anywhere. You know what I put down when I have to write who to notify in case of emergency?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Your lady friend?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: County coroner. 50 LATER - Mueller has rejoined the group. 50

dialogues.speaker: SAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Request permission to have another, sir?

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Ain't nobody gonna tell you you can't have a drink. Someday you're gonna have to tell yourself. Sal signals the bartender to pour another.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Barkeep, I'm gonna have just one more drink... and then I'm gonna have another.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: You have a drinking problem. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: No problem, really. I think I got it down. (offers toast) Born in pain, live in fear, die alone. He chugs it.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Could you be any more Irish right now?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Nope, though my mom was half Italian. I got the best of both - I'm an Irish drinker and an Italian lover. Doc has been watching the TV above the bar. It's the same footage of Saddam getting his physical exam, along with o shots, like the picture of his two sons displayed after t were killed.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I lost one, he lost two.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: I guess he thought it was worth it.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: It wasn't worth it. Not to me. Now George Bush Jr. is on the TV, giving an interview.

dialogues.speaker: DOC, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Would it be worth his twin daughters? He's got twins, right?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Who? The cheerleader? Sal gets up and goes over to the bartender.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: He was a cheerleader in college.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Would it be worth their lives? Even one of ‘em? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Good luck gettin' that answered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three of them come out, Sal and Doc none too steady. go in one direction, stop to get their bearings, then go another direction. Sal spots a phone shop across the stre and attempts to cross in the middle. Mueller hooks him wi his cane and pulls him back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An overwhelming display of hi-tech. A CLERK is helping th

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: How many minutes do I get again?

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: On this plan, five hundred.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Every month?

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Will that be enough?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Enough? How can anybody talk for more than five hundred minutes a month on a fuckin' telephone?

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: We're gonna miss our train, sure as God made little green apples. With a flourish, Sal slaps his MasterCard on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: This goes through, you got a sale young lady, and I go hi-tech. 53 LATER - as Sal signs the papers... 53

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: You can call other people who use this same plan and it won't count against your minutes.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Get out. Now, that's a helluva deal. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: What do you care? Who do you know on this plan?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: You two fuckers! Get you some phones, right now.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Don't need one, don't want one.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I wouldn't mind having one, to tell you the truth. I've often thought about it.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Done! Barkeep, a couple phones for my partners here.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: So he and I can talk anytime, even though he's in Norfolk and I'm in New Hampshire and it don't cost us nothing, right?

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: That's the deal.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: C'mon, Mueller. With three-way calling and all we can talk to each other at the same time.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Well, we're doing that right now, aren't we?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: C'mon, Mueller.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: What if I don't like it? Now I've got a contract for two years?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: What if you fall down? A real possibility with your gimpy knee. And you're in a ditch, and you can't get up, and nobody can see you, and it starts to rain, and the ditch fills up with water? Looks like you're gonna drown. Farewell, old Reverend Mueller. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ah, but with your wireless phone you can call for help.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: And 9-1-1 calls do not count against your minutes. Mueller looks like he is weakening.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Sold!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sal hurries on ahead of the other two, dialing a number o his new phone. He ducks into an enclave off the street an momentarily out of sight. Mueller's phone rings and he fumbles to answer.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: (disguised voice) Is this Reverend Mueller?

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: This is God. It don't count against your minutes to talk with me. They've now caught up with Sal, who emerges with a big sm on his face.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Don't be burning my minutes with foolishness. He hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Call Redman back on the train. They once again fall into pace together as Sal dials.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: (in phone) Hey, Redman, guess who this is! Right! (holds phone against chest) (MORE ) (CONTINUED)
He knew it was me. Listen up, John, I'm calling you on my new wireless... (to Doc) What's my phone number?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: It's in the display.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: What display? There's no number

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: It comes on when you turn on the phone. Sal turns it off and on. He takes a pen out of his pocket writes the number on his palm.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: John? Shit, I lost him.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Well, you hung up on him.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: You don't even know how to use thing. He dials again.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: John Redman, sorry about that. (beat) What? Oh.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: What's he saying?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: They're on their way to Boston.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: The train's left without us?

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Well, that's just outstanding. warned your ass. that

dialogues.speaker: I
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: We'll catch the next one. Redman says they'll wait for us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three of them seem to be wandering in different directions, getting information. Finally they come togeth

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Good news. We can catch the express, right to Boston.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Seven a.m.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Oh, jeez... Mueller gives Sal a withering look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're having dinner at the bar. Sal has his phone on th bar. Mueller has put Doc between them. The bartender swit the TV to a basketball game.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Oh look, a show on black history. Is it that month already?

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Very funny. Back on the game, a player steals the ball, breaks away a goes airborne. He stuffs it.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Let me point out something to you. The butt-ugliest shot in basketball is the slam dunk. What does it mean, anyway? What does it say about the dude who stuffs it?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: That he's pretty darn tall. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Dudes were tall before. They didn't go around hammerin' the ball through the hoop every time down the court. Ugly fuckin' shot and now they're stuck with it. Hangin' on the hoop, all that shit. Now, you take the fade-away jump shot; aman is covered, fenced away from the basket, he goes up, drops back, arcs that puppy over the defense. Beautiful. Elegant. Earl-the-Pearl skillful.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Free throws are what win or lose the game.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Well, but they interrupt the fucking action. They're boring and there are too many of them. You're not supposed to be bangin' into each other. Fouls should be shameful, but, fuck, there ain't no shame anywhere anymore.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Look who's talking. Have you ever been ashamed about anything? Ever in your life?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Only once. They fall silent, then resume their meal.

dialogues.speaker: SAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Boston was where he was from. He expects someone to say something but no one does.

dialogues.speaker: SAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm checking to see if he's got any family still there.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Because he's drunk.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: What does that have to do with it? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: This happen every time you drink?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Pretty much.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Then don't drink.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: It's what I got instead of God.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Okay, I get it. I found God, Doc did his time, and you got drunk.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: And maybe he got the best of the deal.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: He was gonna die anyway, Sal.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: But he didn't have to suffer. Not that much anyway.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Jimmy Hightower! We can't even say his name. We all feel guilty about how he suffered as he was dying, but did it ever occur to you that Maybe nobody would have been shot at all, and everyone would still be alive if we'd all been doing our jobs instead of fuckin' around?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They make their way back to Penn Station.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Now we only got, what, three more hours to wait.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: On the town - two old jarheads and a chicken of the sea.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Only we ain't dancing.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Fuck, we're hardly hobbling. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even Mueller has to smile. Suddenly we hear the odd electronic tones of Raindrops Ke Falling on My Head. Sal jumps, spins around. The music is coming from his chest.

dialogues.speaker: SAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The fuck...!?

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: It's your fancy new phone.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: It does that?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Answer it, Sal. It must be John Redman. Sal digs the phone out of his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: (answering) Hello?

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE PHONE VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (with Indian accent) Mr. Nealon...?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE PHONE VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: My name is Sharon. How are you this evening, Mr. Nealon?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Not all that great, frankly.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE PHONE VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to hear that. I wanted to let you know that my manager will be in your area in the next few days and would love to show you how to make a twelve to twenty percent return by investing in international market funds.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Wait a minute... I don't even know my own fuckin' number, how the hell did you get it? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE PHONE VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Have I called at an inconvenient time?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: What do you think, bitch? He makes like he is going to throw the phone across the street, then smiles and tucks it away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the place comes to life, our three pull their aching b off the benches and try to wake up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the way to Boston, the three of them are half-asleep. stares out of the window.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: What were their names?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: His sons. Saddam's. The ones they shot up and put on display like it was the old Wild West.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Fuck, Doc, it's too early in the day.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I was just thinking.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: I don't know. Weird-ass A-rab names. Hugo and Queasy, like that.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: They were named Uday and Qusay. Fairly simple names.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Sure, if you're used to Leteesha and Kuamme.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: You're a racist as well as an alcoholic. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: You forgot sexist. Fair to everybody. What did you name your kids?

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Otis and Sally.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Now that's nice. A kid should always be able to spell his own name. Named her after me, didn't you? Sally.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Say what?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: After old Sal. I ever have a kid I'll name him after you, Dick. First he'll be little Dick, then he'll grow up to be big Dick.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: What if it was a girl?

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Look at him, Doc. Even if he had any left swimming in him, what woman of childbearing age is gonna spread her legs for him?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Your Sally, if you'll make the introductions. Sal once again jumps out of range of Mueller's cane.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: I swear I'm gonna brain you, I don't care if there's already a plate in your head. I'll put another one ‘em there.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Seriously though, padre, can I ask you a personal question?

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: How come you married a black woman? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Don't you tell me you never had a white woman. It was the 70s.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: As I recall, white dudes finally admitted having an eye for black women .

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, I'm gaga for the sisters myself. And they dig me too. Well, a couple of ‘em did... fora time... then I'd say somethin' stupid.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: No, you? Say something stupid to a black person?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: ‘Course I had a couple bouts of yellow fever too... and always did have a sweet tooth for the Latin babes. I got nothin' against white women, mind you. They're okay, some of ‘em. But we were talkin' about you marrying a black woman.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: First of all, who I married is none of your business.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: That's why I'm being so polite about it.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: I'll tell you why. God told me to.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Whoa. To marry a black girl?

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: No, to marry Ruth.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: He told you that?

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: He did. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Like He told the Reverend Pat Robertson who was gonna win the election?

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Pat Robertson is a complete phony.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: How come God never talks to me?

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Because you can't listen. And he doesn't talk to Pat Robertson either.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: But He does talk to you?

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: I didn't say that. I said He told me to marry Ruth and be a decent man and to preach the word.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: So he does speak to you.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: He didn't talk to me in words. He touched my heart.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Maybe it was Ruth who touched your heart.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Oh, it was. It was God through Ruth. I was down and out, and I didn't care about nothing. A recovering alcoholic with shot up legs. Then one day I found Jesus...

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Where was that, bump into him on the street?

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: In my heart, the only place you can find Him. I went down there like it was a scary cave, which in a way it was, a dark, unexplored place. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Went down afraid and alone, came back up fearless and with Jesus at my side. Next Sunday I took myself to church...

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Hallelujah! And there was Ruth.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Right there, and everything came together for me.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: That's a beautiful story.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Sorry the fuck I asked. (beat) If God wants to keep holdin' out on me, I get it. But would it kill Him to pat me on the shoulder or shake my hand like a man? And if he'd also like to deliver a nice black girl with a great ass, so much the better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walking just outside the Boston train station, Sal is in front of the other two, talking on his cell phone.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: What's he up to?

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Look at him wheeling and dealing... Mr. Cellular Phone. Sal hears them talking about him and turns toward them, s on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: (to Doc and Mueller) We've got an errand to run.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: We got enough time?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Sure. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: (simultaneous) No.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: I'm on with Redman. He and Washington just got to New Hampshire. We'll see ‘em there. (to Redman) We'll see you there. He closes his phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Redman closes his phone and walks back over to the baggag car, where Washington and 5 other service members are starting to carry the box containing the coffin. Redman salutes as they walk away. We follow the mortuary affairs detail through the baggage/storage area of the train station and down an elevator to the loading dock where a hearse, and the fune director LELAND await.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The taxi is driven by a turbaned driver.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: She's been living with it all these years. What good's it gonna do her?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: We're long overdue, the way I figure. She ought to know the truth and we ought to be men enough to say it.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: How'd you find her?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: I got O'Toole to call his granddaughter and have her look it up for us on the world wide web.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: What can we possibly say to her?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: The truth. If it'd a been me, I'd want the other guys to go see my family. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Where is your family?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: They're all dead. I think I have a cousin left, in Scranton. The cab pulls up to a small house. They look at the place say nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the door: Mueller knocks with his cane. They wait. He knocks again.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Maybe nobody lives here anymore, maybe. The door opens, revealing a woman in her 80s. She is wary

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HIGHTOWER
dialogues.text: Yes? None of them seems able to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some time later, they're all sitting around in the living room. Mrs. Hightower directs them through a series of fra pictures and Christmas card photos that they pass around.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HIGHTOWER
dialogues.text: This was the last picture we ever got from Jimmy. And this is Jimmy's little girl all grown up.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: So, how old was she when he died?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HIGHTOWER
dialogues.text: Four months old. Her mom eventually remarried and they moved to San Diego. Here's my great-grandkids.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Look at that. He'd be a grandfather.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HIGHTOWER
dialogues.text: I've never met them in person, but they call every now and then. So you three were with my Jimmy? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old woman stares at him blankly.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Yes ma'am. We'd already fought us a long year, and most of us were still breathing. But that extension... that four more months they added on... some of us couldn't handle it, and, I think we didn't all...

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HIGHTOWER
dialogues.text: What was it all for?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: They said they knew, and we believed them. But now... we just came here to tell you what happened.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HIGHTOWER
dialogues.text: Are you some of the men he saved? Sal is just frozen. Doc and Mueller look at him wondering how he's going to respond.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HIGHTOWER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thry told me he saved three or four of his buddies, before...

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Yes ma'am. We are.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: He was a great guy, Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Yeah, we've never forgotten him.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: That's why we're here, ma'am. We owe him.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: We just wanted to come by and pay our respects.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Let you know he's still in our hearts.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HIGHTOWER
dialogues.text: That is so sweet of you boys. I can't thank you enough.  64 65 66 67 92.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens as they exit. Sal gets the last hug in.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Take care of yourself.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HIGHTOWER
dialogues.text: This makes my week. Please come back anytime.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Thank you, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Bless you, Mrs. Hightower.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HIGHTOWER
dialogues.text: You boys be careful out there.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: We will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sit in silence, not saying much. Even Sal stares out the window at the sunset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Washington waits for them, next to a hearse and Leland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Washington sits next to Leland. In the back seat are Sal, and Mueller. Outside the window are shells of abandoned plants and factories, lying idle. Sal just stares out the window.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Looks like things used to get made here.

dialogues.speaker: LELAND
dialogues.text: Used to.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Even morticians better watch out - they might be outsourcing undertakin' next. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LELAND
dialogues.text: Never happen - American funeral directors are the best in the world. Sal mutters a monologue... not that anyone is much listen at this point.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: So were the American factories. We could make anything, quality stuff. That's how we won two world wars. Don't be surprised if somebody figures out that it's cheaper to ship a body to Mexico and back than to do it up here. They'll ship it to China or India once they figure out it'll save 'em a buck. Don't matter how good you are. (new mumbly thought) Just a matter of time till they start outsourcing soldiering. Hell, get a bunch of starving young people from all over the world, put ‘em in a uniform and tell ‘em to try to stay alive. When their tour is over we ship 'em back to where they came from... no VA hospitals, or pensions. You lost an arm? You got PTSD? Tough shit, we're flushing you down...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The limo pulls into the driveway. As the others get out, quickly goes to the nearest bush in the yard to pee.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: If you had any more manners, you'd be a dog. Sal continues peeing, emphasizing his relief.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Now I'm seeing God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the small, dark den, embers glow in the fireplace. Washington lies awake on the sofa.  70 71

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mueller lies awake. He can't help but notice the pictures Doc and his wife, Larry Jr, etc. Actually, it feels like Mary still lives there. It seems Doc's barely touched anything since last January.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sal is laying on a trundle bed, pulled out from under Lar bed, where Doc rests. The room is lit by moonlight. Now a as-he-left-it shrine to Larry, they're surrounded by the various photos of family and friends, sports mementoes, m posters, etc.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: You gonna want to stay on here, alone?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I don't know - haven't thought much about it.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Portsmouth? The brig right there. You might want to try another place. A fresh start.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: But Larry would be here. Mary, too.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: You could always come visit. You got close friends here?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Not too many. Not too close. His voice trails, he's falling asleep. Sal jabs him in th ribs.

dialogues.speaker: DOC, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Move to Norfolk. You could work in my bar.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I never worked in a bar before.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Trust me - it ain't that hard. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Your place don't seem all that busy.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: That's my fault. I let it go. It needs new blood. We could get the grill part going again. I need a partner.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: A partner?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Yeah. The bar'd be half yours, and when I bite it, it'll be all yours.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Sal... you don't owe me nothing.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: This ain't paying off no debt. I really do need a partner, and I got nobody to leave the place to. You could stay with me for a while, but then you'd have to find your own place, 'cause I like to pursue the ladies and, frankly, you'd cramp my style.

dialogues.speaker: SAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You thinkin' about it?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I am. I'm picturing it. It's kinda funny.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Might be time for another BCD in your life. Doc smiles.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Better career decision...

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Yeah, and if nothin' else, it might be fun. What's wrong with that?  72 INT. DOC'S HOUSE —- MORNING Sal, Mueller and Washington are in the kitchen having Sal punches some numbers in his cell phone, waits for answer.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: You purely love that thing, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: I can't get that fucker O'Toole to answer. The place could be burned down for all I know. He puts the phone away. Doc comes in with a suit ona hangar.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Larry's graduation suit.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Looks a little small.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: You think?

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Larry bulked up. That's gonna be way too tight on him.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I guess I could go down to Penny's and buy him something new.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: We still got his dress blues.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Remember how we used to call the dress blues the tuxedo? By law you could go to any formal function wearing that uniform.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Not that we ever got invited to one... or would have gone if we did.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Still, it was good to know you were always dressed for any occasion. 96. 72 coffee. an (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: No one ever forgets the first time you put it on and looked at yourself in the mirror - I'm in the U.S. Marine Corps, and I look pretty fuckin' good.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: I do remember that feeling.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. I'm glad to know you never forget it.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Larry must have looked sharp.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: He did. He was proud as a peacock in that uniform.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: I know that for a fact.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Pride is the thing. (to Mueller) It's no sin.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: No, of course not. Not that kind.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I could bury him in his dress uniform, even if.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Yeah. It means you did something. You served. Fuck what the politicians did, you served. You didn't weasel out of it. You didn't think it was somebody else's job. You took it on, man, and you looked sharp doing it.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: I'm gonna. I'm gonna bury him in his uniform.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Never regret it, sir. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Fuckin' A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Establishing shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc is in the background, talking to Leland about various details. Washington, forever on duty, stands next to the coffin. In the foyer, Sal and Mueller sit on opposing benches, waiting for Doc. Sal is studying Mueller, lookin him over his folded arms.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Why're you looking at me like that?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: I'm sizin' you up. I'm gonna buy you a new suit of clothes.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Say what?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: I'm gonna dress you up for the occasion.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Why, may I ask?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Because I love you.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: I don't need a new suit of clothes. It's you needs some grooming.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Neither of us is properly dressed. But we will be, you watch.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER

dialogues.text: Dear Dad. If you are reading this, then you've been notified. I was always prepared to sacrifice my life for my country. You have to be ready to die defending what you love.
